DOC.brief_summary: Meditation is an approach that focuses on the connection between mind and body that uses techniques with breath, sound, or movement. It has been the focus of research because of its possible benefit for lowering distress and improving health and quality of life. The meditation techniques in this study are already used in clinical practice. They are based on the Tibetan tradition and focus on use of sound and breathing techniques. The goal of this research study is to learn how self-administered meditation (meditation participant completes on their own) can improve participant's mood-related symptoms, such as depression and anxiety. Researchers also want to learn how to deliver pre-recorded meditations using a computer-based application (program, or "app").
DOC.brief_title: Self-Administered Meditation Intervention for Cancer Patients With Psychosocial Distress
DOC.detailed_description: Baseline Visit: Participant has already had assessments as part of participant's routine care that helped show that participant was eligible to take part in this study. If participant agrees to take part in this study, the following tests and procedures will be performed at participant's first study visit: - Participant's vital signs (blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, and breathing rate) will be measured. - Participant's medical history will be collected. - Participant will be asked about any drugs participant may be taking and any side effects participant may be having. - Participant will complete a questionnaire about how participant feels about meditation. This questionnaire should take about 5 minutes to complete. - Participant will complete a basic demographic information (ethnicity, gender, age, and so on) questionnaire. This questionnaire should take about 5 minutes to complete. - Participant will complete 4 questionnaires about any symptoms participant may have. The questionnaires should take about 15-20 minutes total to complete. Study Groups: After the baseline visit has been completed, participant will be randomly assigned (as in the toss of a coin) to 1 of 2 study groups. - If participant is enrolled in Group 1, participant will be given access to a computer-based meditation program for 2 weeks. - If participant is enrolled in Group 2, participant will be in the control group and will receive access to social workers, support groups, spiritual care, and other patient services. Meditation Group (Group 1): If participant is in Group 1, participant will be given a device (such as a phone, tablet, or computer) that has the meditation app already installed on it. On participant's first day, participant will watch a pre-recorded video in the app that tells participant about the practice of meditation and what to expect during meditation (for example, participant will do deep breathing and visualization exercises). Participant will return the device at the end of your participation. If the device is lost, damaged, or stolen please tell the research staff as soon as possible. Participant will be encouraged to meditate at least 1 time every day for up to 2 weeks using the meditation app. Participant will be able to set a reminders through the meditation app. Each day, participant will open the app and select a 5-, 10-, or 15-minute long meditation session that participant will follow along with. Participant will complete a questionnaire about participant's mood before and after each meditation session through the app which will take less than 1 minute to complete each time. The app will track how many times participant meditates each day, how long participant meditates for, and when participant meditates. This information, including participant's mood questionnaire responses, will be sent to the study staff. Control Group (Group 2): If participant is assigned to the waitlist control group participant will not receive the meditation app for the first 2 weeks. Participant will have access to participant's doctor as well as access to social workers, support groups, spiritual care, and other patient services. All Participants: At the end of the study period, all participants may have access to the meditation guidance recordings (audio files only), if requested. Length of Study: Participation on this study will last up to 2 weeks.Participant will no longer be able to take part in meditation if participant's symptoms gets worse or if participant is unable to follow study directions. Participation in this study will be over after participant has completed the end-of-study visit. End-of-Study: After participant has completed the meditation program for Group 1 or after 2 weeks for Group 2: - Participant's vital signs will be measured. - Participant's medical history will be recorded. - Participant will be asked about any drugs participant may be taking and any side effects participant may be having. - Participant will complete the same 4 questionnaires that participant completed at screening. - Participant will have an interview with a member of the study staff. Participant will be asked questions about participant's opinions on meditation and if participant thinks they benefitted from meditation. This interview should take about 10 minutes to complete. This is an investigational study. The use of meditation for anxiety in cancer patients is considered investigational. The lead researcher can explain how meditation is designed to work. Up to 30 participants will be enrolled in this study. All will take part at MD Anderson.
DOC.criteria: 1. Patients at MD Anderson with a cancer history who are either undergoing active treatment or who have completed treatment for their cancer. 2. Must understand and read English, sign a written informed consent, and follow protocol requirements. 3. Age >/= 18 years willing to come to MD Anderson Main Campus (Texas Medical Center) for enrollment. 4. Patient selfreported ESAS psychological scale score (sum of anxiety and depression scores) greater than or equal to 4 (and/or) individual anxiety or depression score greater than or equal to 4 on a 0 to 10 numeric scale, where 10 is the worst possible. 5. If on medication for anxiety, stable dose of medications for management of anxiety symptoms for at least six weeks prior to enrollment with no plans to change meditations in the subsequent four weeks. Increases or decreases allowed within drug class, but changing drug class will make patient inevaluable. 1. Diagnosis of a formal thought disorder (e.g., schizophrenia). 2. Known history of a neurological and/or psychological disorder that in the physician's opinion may interfere with the patient's ability to cooperate with study procedures.
